A ring (admitting a unit element) is a set R together with two laws of composition written as addition '+' and multiplication '.' such that: (i) R is a commutative group with respect to addition. (ii) R is a monoid with respect to multiplication, i.e., the multiplication is associative, and there exists a unit element in R. (iii) The distributive laws hold, i.e., (a+b) 
cdot c=a 
cdot c+b 
cdot c, and c 
cdot(a+b)=c 
cdot a+c 
cdot b for all a, b, c in R.
Let $G$ be a monoid. A subset $H \subset G$ is called a submonoid if $H$ satisfies the following conditions: (i) $e \in H$, (ii) $a, b \in H \Longrightarrow a b \in H$.
Does the concept of a/an Ring need to be defined for a definition of a/an Submonoid to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a submonoid is defined strictly within the context of a monoid. A submonoid is a subset of a monoid that itself forms a monoid under the same operation as the original monoid. The definition of a submonoid requires the subset to contain the identity element of the monoid and to be closed under the monoid operation.

On the other hand, a ring is a more complex algebraic structure that includes two operations: addition and multiplication. While a ring is a monoid with respect to its multiplication operation, the concept of a ring also involves additional structures and properties, such as being a commutative group under addition and obeying the distributive laws.

Therefore, understanding or defining a submonoid does not require the concept of a ring. The definition of a submonoid is complete with reference to the properties of monoids alone, without any need to reference or involve the additional structures that define a ring.
